author: @ketan_sahu
text:
In case someone wants to know how to redirect to the same page where the user has made the login request, here's a way: {% extends 'base_layout.html' %} {% block content %}

Login

{% csrf_token %} {{ form }} {% if request.GET.next %} {% endif %}
{% endblock %} in the login form, we are checking if there is a "next" attribute in the request (if a request comes from any page then the link to that page is stored in the "next" variable). If yes then we send it along in the post request made to log in as above. and then in the view, we do the following: def login_view(request): if request.method == 'POST': form = AuthenticationForm(data=request.POST) if form.is_valid(): user = form.get_user() login(request, user) if 'next' in request.POST: return redirect(request.POST.get('next')) else: return redirect('articles:list') else: form = AuthenticationForm() return render(request, 'accounts/login.html', { 'form': form }) we check if there is a "next" attribute in the POST request and the user is authenticated then we the user in and redirect him/her to the link stored in the "next".

text: This is interesting and pellucid tutorial. Awesome!!!  But a tiny problem with navbar did occur: navbar should be dynamic when a user registers/logs in an account thus repetitive "register"/"login" should disappear(otherwise the corresponding url becomes /register/register), leaving only either "login" or "register".   Since my navbar does not know whether I am on register page or login page (or it does just not that I know of), I had to copy and paste the header.html to both register.html and login.html, before toggling the <nav></nav> interchangeably. Is there a way to achieve this through full utilization of Jinja templating?

author: @Skaxarrat
text: If you want to learn what Django does (what it really really does), instead of documentation, that oftentimes can be a bit...cryptic, google what you want to find and go for the Django github.  For example, in the video Sentdex search for authenticate only to find this: from django.contrib.auth import authenticate user = authenticate(username='john', password='secret')  But if you instead go for the Github repo you'll find more information AND how the function works:  def authenticate(self, request, username=None, password=None, **kwargs):     if username is None:         username = kwargs.get(UserModel.USERNAME_FIELD)     try:         user = UserModel._default_manager.get_by_natural_key(username)     except UserModel.DoesNotExist:         # Run the default password hasher once to reduce the timing         # difference between an existing and a nonexistent user (#20760).         UserModel().set_password(password)     else:         if user.check_password(password) and self.user_can_authenticate(user):             return user
